posts.name: Arjun Bhatia
posts.cooked:
I am doing a review of our team’s COTS library for SolidWorks and I am curious to see how teams structure their library folders. I figure there are two main ways of doing this:

By Part Type: for example, all 1/2" hex hubs are in one folder regardless of vendor, so am-4777 and REV-21-2017 would be in the same folder. When you sort by name, you can easily see which ones belong to which vendor by their suffix (e.g. AM - vs. REV-).

By Part Type: for example, all 1/2" hex hubs are in one folder regardless of vendor, so am-4777 and REV-21-2017 would be in the same folder. When you sort by name, you can easily see which ones belong to which vendor by their suffix (e.g. AM - vs. REV-).

By Vendor: This is what we do now. There would be outer folders for each vendor (e.g. AndyMark, REV, WCP ) and inner folders for each part type. So am-4777 would be in AndyMark > Sprocket and Chain and REV-21-2017 would be in REV Robotics > Sprocket and Chain .

By Vendor: This is what we do now. There would be outer folders for each vendor (e.g. AndyMark, REV, WCP ) and inner folders for each part type. So am-4777 would be in AndyMark > Sprocket and Chain and REV-21-2017 would be in REV Robotics > Sprocket and Chain .

Option 1 seems to make sense, since when you need a gear, you want to see all the gears available, but I also see a lot of teams going with 2.

It would be great if you explained your rationale below, especially if your team has tried both.

posts.name: Vaughn Khouri
posts.cooked:
Considering that so many COTs libraries already exist and are great, if you are taking the time to make your own I would go ahead and do some standardization. Having less choices and effective part duplicates makes it easier for new designers to understand what they’re looking at when designing a mechanism.

So yes, sort by part type, but just only include gears/sprockets/whatever else  from one vendor, including others only when that vendor is missing stuff (eg a certain tooth count gear)

For us, that’s WCP because we’re located close to them and can get parts in 1-2 days, and their products consistently meet our expectations.
